title-group.article-title: Kinrentius Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010 (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae): description of two new species and taxonomic key to the genus

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Kinrentius Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
( Hemiptera : Cicadellidae : Deltocephalinae ): description of two new species and taxonomic key to the genus
BEATRIZ M. CAMISÃO 1* , CLAYTON C. GONÇALVES 1,2 & DANIELA M. TAKIYA 1,3

1
Laboratório de Entomologia, Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro , Caixa Postal 6244, 21941-971, Rio de Janeiro , RJ, Brazil .

2
Ễ
clayton.correa.goncalves@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-3045-3425

3
Ễ
takiya@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-6233-3615

* Corresponding author:
Ễ biacamisao@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9091-5404

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Two new species of the South American genus
Kinrentius
are described and illustrated.
Kinrentius catuaba
sp. nov.
from Brazil ( Acre , Amazonas and Rondônia states) can be distinguished by the male pygofer with multidentate anteroventral and posteroventral processes with short dentiform processes between them and aedeagus with dorsal projection forming a distinct process and apex with paired apical processes, each subrectangular, with apical margin irregularly serrated in caudal view.
Kinrentius peruvianus
sp. nov.
from Peru ( Cusco and Madre de Dios departments) has short male pygofer posteroventral processes and aedeagus more robust and parallel sided in dorsal view, with paired apical processes, each subquadrate, with apical portion weekly sclerotized, and apical margin approximately straight and slightly serrate in caudal view. A taxonomic key to males and a distribution map of all four species of the genus are provided.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words :
Bahitini
, leafhoppers , morphology , Neotropical region

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Kinrentius Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
was described based on specimens from Colombia , Ecuador , and Peru , to accommodate two species:
K. bispinosus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
and
K. constrictus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
. These authors observed that, despite several morphological resemblances to members of the Old-World tribe Stegelytrini Baker, 1915 , they attributed these similarities to evolutionary convergence because
Kinrentius
also exhibits several characters in common with more derived members of Deltocephalinae . Therefore,
Kinrentius
was treated as unplaced within
Deltocephalinae ( Wei, Dietrich & Webb 2010 )
.

provided a phylogeny for Deltocephalinae based on a combined molecular and morphological dataset that supported the placement of
Kinrentius
in the tribe Bahitini .
included
K. constrictus
in the most extensive molecular phylogeny performed for the subfamily to date, and it was recovered as the sister group of the monotypic Bahitini genus
Oxycephalotettix Zahniser, 2005
, but this branch appears nestled inside a larger clade encompassing several neotropical representatives of the tribes Athysanini , Bahitini, and
Penthimiini (
Cao et al. 2022
)
. This highlights the need for further investigations regarding the phylogeny of neotropical Deltocephalinae including genera comprised in Bahitini .

Herein, two new species of
Kinrentius
are described and illustrated. A taxonomic key to males and a map of distribution are provided.

sec.title: Material & Methods
sec.p:
Eighteen specimens were studied:
K. constrictus
(5),
K. catuaba
sp. nov.
(10), and
K. peruvianus
sp. nov.
(3). The material was obtained during collecting trips to Acre , Amazonas and Rondônia ( Brazil ) and Cusco and Madre de Dios ( Peru ).All pinned vouchers are deposited in the Coleção de Invertebrados do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas de Amazônia (Manaus, INPA ), Coleção Entomológica Prof. José Alfredo Pinheiro Dutra, Departamento de Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (Rio de Janeiro, DZRJ ), Museu Nacional do Rio de Janeiro (Rio de Janeiro, MNRJ ), Museu de Zoologia da Universidade de São Paulo (São Paulo, MZSP ), and in the Museo de Historia Natural, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos ( Lima , MUSM ).

A Leica EC3 digital camera coupled to a Leica S8 APO stereomicroscope was used to photograph the external morphology and male genitalia of the new species. Abdomens of specimens were removed and soaked in hot 10% KOH solution for 10 to 20 minutes, then rinsed in a water bath. Dissected genitalia were stored in a glycerin-filled microvial attached to the insect pin below the rest of the specimen. Terminology follows
for external morphology and male genitalia, and
for leg chaetotaxy. Abbreviations used in the descriptions of leg chaetotaxy are as follows: AD = anterodorsal; AV = anteroventral; and PV = posteroventral. Label data are quoted verbatim , with a backslash (\) separating lines on labels. The distribution map was compiled based on shape layers and rendered in QGIS® 2.8.4. (qgis.org). Terminology for ecological systems is as defined by
.

Cao et al. (2022)
(Phylogeny of Deltocephalinae ).

Type-species:
Kinrentius bispinosus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
, by original designation. Length : 8.7–13.2 mm .

sec.title:

Kinrentius
sec.p:
Kinrentius catuaba
sp. nov. Brazil ( Acre , Amazonas, Rondônia ).

Kinrentius constrictus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
. Peru ( Cusco ).

Kinrentius peruvianus
sp. nov. Peru ( Cusco , Madre de Dios ).

- Pygofer, in lateral view, with apex broadly rounded (
in Wei, Dietrich & Webb 2010 ), ventral margin without processes; aedeagus strongly constricted sub-basally between preatrium and shaft ( Wei, Dietrich & Webb 2010 :
)...........................................................................
K. constrictus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010

- Pygofer with anteroventral and posteroventral processes not multidentate, without teeth between processes; aedeagus median portion with dorsal projection small, tooth-like, and apical paired processes, in lateral view, moderately expanded and with anterior margin acute ( Wei, Dietrich & Webb 2010 :
,
)...........
K. bispinosus Wei, Dietrich & Webb, 2010
.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type locality.
Fazenda Experimental Catuaba , Senador Guiomard , Acre State , Brazil
.
Length . 8.75–9.45 mm .
Female terminalia. Female unknown.
Etymology. The new species is named after the type-locality, Fazenda Experimental Catuaba, Brazil . The epithet is in apposition to the generic name.

Notes :
K. catuaba
sp. nov.
is similar to
K. bispinosus
and
K. peruvianus
sp. nov.
in sharing paired anteroventral (AVP) and posteroventral (PVP) processes on the ventral margin of the male pygofer. However, the new species can be distinguished by the multidentate antero- and posteroventral processes (
), presence of short dentiform projections between ventral processes (
), and aedeagus with well-developed dorsal projection forming a distinct spine at mid-length (
).

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type locality:
Tambopata , Madre de Dios , Peru
.
Length : 8.7–9.0 mm

Coloration : Color pattern as in
Kinrentius catuaba
sp. nov.
Female terminalia: Female unknown.
Etymology: The new species’ epithet refers to its Peruvian distribution.

Notes :
Kinrentius peruvianus
sp. nov.
is similar to
K. bispinosus
and
K. catuaba
sp. nov .
(see notes in previous species). However, the new species can be distinguished from other
Kinrentius
by the short tooth-like posteroventral process (PVP) of male pygofer (
), aedeagus without a pronounced dorsal projection at mid-length and apical processes subquadrate with apical margin straight and slightly serrate (
).

, “ PERU , Madre de Dios , \ Tambopata , Res. Zone \ Tambopata ; Research Rio \ Tambopata ;

; C.R. Bartlett ” ( MUSM )
.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The present work doubles the number of
Kinrentius
species and makes an important contribution to the taxonomy of the tribe Bahitini by adding distinctive characters useful for further investigations. Furthermore, it also provides a taxonomic key facilitating the identification of species.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We would like to thank anonymous reviewers who kindly contributed improvements to an early version of this manuscript. C. Bartlett (University of Delaware) for donating a Peruvian specimen. We thank J.A. Rafael (Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia) for coordinating the project “Biodiversidade de Insecta na Amazônia—rede BIA” funded by Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq Proc. 407627/2013-8) and making available the leafhopper material for our study. BMC had a doctoral fellowship from CNPq (Proc. 142366/2014-5) for part of the development of this study. CCG is post-doctoral fellow from Fundação Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo à Pesquisa do Rio de Janeiro (FAPERJ Proc. E-26/202.301/2019). DMT is research productivity fellow from CNPq (Proc. 314557/2021-0) and Cientista do Nosso Estado fellow from FAPERJ (Proc. E-26/200.503/2023).
